0.text:
GREG FOOT: This is the
Wartime Broadcasting Service.

3.text:
This country has been attacked
with nuclear weapons.

6.text:
The number of casualties and the extent of
the damage are not yet known.

10.text:
Stay tuned to this wavelength, stay calm,
and stay in your own homes.

14.text:
TOM SCOTT: This is the nuclear bunker at Kelvedon
Hatch, in Essex, and that's Greg from the

19.text:
BBC's BritLab reading the actual script that
a BBC newsreader would have sent out from

24.text:
somewhere if the Cold War had become Hot.
If that had happened, then this would have

29.text:
been one of 25 Regional Seats of Government:
this is where volunteers would have tried

33.text:
to ride out the nuclear exchange and lead
the country through... well, whatever followed.

39.text:
Their job was not to save lives immediately:
if you were in the blast radius of a nuclear

44.text:
weapon, you wouldn't last long. But in the
days and weeks that followed, one of their

48.text:
jobs would have been to predict fallout: the
radioactive dust and debris blasted into the

53.text:
atmosphere by nuclear bombs. They'd work out
when survivors could leave their homes -- what

58.text:
was left of their homes -- without too much
risk of radiation poisoning, and pass that

63.text: on to whatever local civil defence still existed.

66.text:
But how would they have worked that out, down
here in a bunker as the world literally ended

72.text:
Well mostly, they'd have used special pinhole
cameras left above ground: a tin can with

77.text:
a few holes in it and photographic film on
the inside. The blinding flash from a nuclear

82.text:
weapon would leave a mark on the photographic
film. It'd record an imprint with the bearing

87.text:
and the height. And the plan was that some
poor sod would leave the bunker very quickly,

91.text:
fetch the film, and then they'd triangulate
with other bunkers and work out: ground bursts

96.text:
that produce local fallout, air bursts that
spread it much wider, where, when? They could

101.text:
measure the pressure wave, the blast wave
as it went across based on some fairly simple

106.text:
equipment, and then they could help work out
the yield of the bombs. And they'd draw it

110.text:
all up on this big board, and then, based
on that, weather observations, and reports

116.text:
coming in from smaller, remote bunkers, start
making some very horrible calculations.

122.text:
And in some bunkers, including this one, they
had AWDREY, an electronic system. Now AWDREY

127.text:
is the Atomic Weapons Detection Recognition
and Estimation of Yield, and someone must

132.text: have been really proud of that acronym.

135.text:
It was all rather optimistic, odd though that
might sound. It'll be a disaster, they said,

139.text:
but we'll help people through, we'll be able
to get weather reports and we'll have local

143.text:
centres of government keeping everything together.
But Britain is a small, densely populated

150.text:
country. Our National Archives has a list
of what our government thought would be Soviet

154.text:
targets: every major city, every military
base. It's safe to say that not many people

159.text:
would have survived even a day or two, and
only very few would have made it a month,

163.text:
let alone a year. And there's nothing anyone
on the planet could have done in the event

167.text:
of a full-scale nuclear war -- it would change
the climate and be an extinction level event.

173.text:
But in what was called a limited exchange,
there were places in Britain that could've

178.text:
survived, outside blast areas, remote countryside
and perhaps a few seaside towns like Brighton

183.text:
and Aberystwyth that were well away from any
strategic targets. And maybe, some of us,

188.text: with help from here, might have made it through.

191.text: I'm doing some videos with BBC BritLab.

195.text:
If you want to see what this mess is about,
click the link on screen or in the description.

203.text:
We shall repeat this broadcast in two hours'
time.

206.text:
Stay tuned to this wavelength, but switch
your radios off now

209.text:
to save your batteries until we
come on the air again.

212.text: That is the end of the broadcast.
